description.narrative: This project is a low emission capacity building project focuses on strengthening Uganda’s technical and institutional capacity in the development of Green House Gas inventory systems and Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions.
independent political entity

1. Thematic working group on GHG inventory system and national dialogue platforms and coordination mechanisms established. 2. Number of Nationally Appropriate Mitigation actions (NAMAs) full proposals in place 3. MRVs for HG inventory systems and NAMAs in place 4. Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

comment.narrative: 1. There are no thematic working groups and dialogue platforms on GHG inventory systems in place. 2. There is no systematic Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs) development full proposal yet. 3. There is no MRV for GHG Inventory system and NAMA in place. 4. No Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

1. Thematic working group on GHG inventory system and national dialogue platforms and coordination mechanisms established. 2. Number of Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMA) full proposals in place. 3. MRV for GHG inventory systems and NAMAs in place. 4. A Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

1. A GHG inventory and data collection system established and institutionalized, including inventory management capacity built at national level. 2. Bankable proposals with private sector lead business models developed for 4 NAMAs and submitted for financing 3. A National Green growth Strategy developed and operationalized. 4. Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

1. The GHG inventory system was developed with a direct linkage to the Climate Change Department Knowledge Management System (KMS), the national Climate Atlas and Performance Management Framework (PMF). The inventory includes sector specific GHG data and a digital/e-library. 2. The Green Schools NAMA, an integrated sustainable energy solution for schools in Uganda was finalized and submitted to the NAMA Facility. It is a huge potential for GHG emission reductions through the introduction of Institutional Improved Cook Stoves (IICS), which will be introduced in 15,750 Ugandan schools, representing 75% of all Ugandan schools and is worth USD 15 Million. A waste-to energy NAMA concept finalized and submitted to the UNFCCC portal for elaboration of a fully-fledged proposal for funding by GEF. A fuel efficiency and vehicle inspection NAMA was elaborated so that transport and energy efficiency is integrated in NDC, targeting how private sector and financial institutions can be involved and offer financing. For the agriculture sector, a livestock based NAMA was elaborated. 3. The Green Growth strategy was developed and presented for national adoption. 4. The Nationally Determined Contributions were finalized and submitted to the UNFCCC as part of national obligations in the Paris Agreement.

1. A GHG inventory and data collection system established and institutionalized, including inventory management capacity built at national level. 2. Bankable proposals with private sector lead business models developed for 2 NAMAs and submitted for financing 3. A functional National Green growth Strategy . 4. Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

1. A functional GHG inventory and data collection system in place.Project Audit and Project terminal evaluation finalized 2. Support to Development of Inclusive Markets in Tourism.Implementing agency is Uganda Tourism Board with Enterprise Uganda as the RP. The duration of the project is 2011-2015.
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

1. No. of contracts between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. No. of Memorandum of understanding signed 3. No. of MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. No of tourism support institutions strengthened

comment.narrative: Tourism has a high potential for income generation and has been identified as one of the priority sectors by Government. However, the tourism sector is still underdeveloped, with a weak policy and regulatory framework; limited access to markets; limited product scope, weak business and technical skills; weak value chains. The following was the project baseline status: 1. Zero contracts between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. Zero Memorandum of understanding signed 3. Zero MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. Zero tourism support institutions strengthened

1. 12 contracts/business linkages between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. 10 Memorandum of understanding signed 3. 15 MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. 3 tourism support institutions strengthened

1. 12 business linkages between key market off-takers and MSMEs were strengthened, which has resulted in increased access to markets by the small enterprises (MSMEs), as well as growth of their businesses.
2. 15 Memorandum of understanding signed 3. 15 MSME's in tourism strengthened through extensive trainings 4. Overall five (three tourism business support associations and two tourism support institutions) was strengthened in areas of quality assurance, research and evidence-based planning; development and implementation of sustainable marketing and branding strategies as well as development of their 5 year Strategic Plans

1. 16 contracts/business linkages between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. 14 Memorandum of understanding signed 3. 20 MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. 5 tourism support institutions strengthened
a. Uganda Tourism Board Strategic Plan 2016/17 - 2020/21 developed b. Kampala Urban Tourism Development Strategy developed c. Inclusive Business Ecosystem for Tourism Mapped

1. 16 contracts/business linkages between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. 14 Memorandum of understanding signed 3. 20 MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. 5 tourism support institutions strengthened a). The Uganda Tourism Strategic Plan 2016/17 - 2020/21 was developed. The Strategy provides a roadmap for translation of the national vision and SDGs into specific interventions. b). The Kampala Urban Tourism Development Strategy was developed. It provides a roadmap for the growth and coordination of urban tourism development in the five divisions of Kampala as well as the establishment of urban tourism support infrastructure. c). A Mapping Study of the Tourism inclusive Business Ecosystem System in Uganda was undertaken. The study provides critical information for the strengthen of the ecosystem to ensure its inclusive and low income persons are able to benefit from participating in the tourism value chain
Project operationally closed
Project operationally closed

description.narrative: IMPROVING POLICIES AND STRATEGIES FOR SUSTAINABLE ENVIRONMENT, NATURAL RESOURCES AND CLIMATE RISK MITIGATION
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Diagnostic study report on the review of the National Environment Management Policy (NEMP), related policies, laws and strategies in place. 2. Draft Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) sectoral guidelines for the energy, agriculture and, mining in place. 3. Strategy for management of Electronic waste in place. 4. Draft national biomass energy strategy in place. 5. Capacity building programme in place 5.1 National institutional capacity needs assessment report for Climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management. 5.2 Training manual for climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management.

comment.narrative: 1. The National Environment Management Policy (1994) is in place but not reviewed or updated to cater for emerging environmental challenges. 2. The National Environmental Impact Assessment Regulations are in place but no EIA sectoral guidelines (for agriculture, mining, energy and other key sectors). 3. There is an electronic waste management policy but no strategy for management of electronic waste in place. 4. No national biomass energy strategy in place. 5.1 There is a National Disaster Preparedness and Management Policy and platform in place but there is an inadequate capacity for coordination of Climate risk management. 5.2 Most relevant government officials are inadequately skilled in climate risk management.

3. Strategy for management of Electronic waste in place. 4. National biomass energy strategy in place. 5. There is inadequate application of EBA Methodologies and tools at ecosystem level in Mountain Elgon ecosystem. 3. 1. Methodologies and tools for Ecosystem Based Adaptation (EBA) decision making in place 2. EBA Methodologies and tools at ecosystem level in Mountain Elgon ecosystem in place. 3. EBA pilot projects being implemented in Mountain Elgon ecosystem to contribute towards ecosystem resilience and reduction in livelihood vulnerability. 4. Availability of information and capacities in place for Key Government stakeholders to integrate EBA into national development and climate change policies, plans and strategies.

1.Methodologies and tools for Ecosystem Based Adaptation (EBA) decision making in place. 2 reports of; Cost-benefit Analysis of EbA options and the Policy and Financing processes Framework on EbA were finalized and printed. It highlights the cost effective EbA options to enable building a business case for EbA.
2.EBA Methodologies and tools at ecosystem level in Mountain Elgon ecosystem in place. A socioeconomic assessment was conducted to provide a description of the baseline conditions in the working area before the implementation of the Payments for Environmental Services (PES) and Grants as incentives for Ecosystem Based Adaptation to climate change for Bulambuli and Sironko Districts in the Mt. Elgon Ecosystem.
3. EBA pilot projects being implemented in Mountain Elgon ecosystem to contribute towards ecosystem resilience and reduction in livelihood vulnerability.
4.Information and capacities are in place for Key Government stakeholders to integrate EBA into national development and climate change policies, plans and strategies. Up to 900 households within Sironko and Bulambuli have been trained in EBA integration, the principles of Payment for Ecosystem Services (input & performance based system) out of whom 650 households working in up to 90 groups have applied to participate in this initiative targeting the Sironko, Sisiyi, Simu and Sipi river catchments. A training manual in place on how to integrate EbA into policy and financing frameworks.

1. Methodologies and tools for EBA decision making in place e.g Payment for Ecosystems Services schemes in 4 Subscounties completed 2: EBA Methodologies and tools at ecosystem level in Mountain Elgon ecosystem in place e.g District Climate Change Adaptation Centres for Sironko and Bulambuli completed.. 3: Available information and capacities in place for Key Government stakeholders to integrate EBA into national development and climate change policies, plans and strategies. e.g Lessons learned from EBA pilot projects captured and disseminated

1. Payment for Ecosystems Services schemes in 4 Sub counties completed (details). 2: District Climate Change Adaptation Centres for Sironko and Bulambuli completed and launched by the Minister of Water and Environment). 3: Capacities built for key Government stakeholders to integrate EBA into national development and climate change policies, plans and strategies. E.g. EBA training manual prepared/ disseminated. 4. Lessons learned from EBA pilot projects disseminated at Global Mountain Forum held in Mbale Town.

PA buffer zone under approved district management plans in six districts Kitgum Kaabong Agago Otuke Abim and Kotido incorporating BD considerations

description.narrative: Deforestation community wildlife agreements

comment.narrative: Cooperation between UWA and NFA is relatively limited cooperation between different districts is minimal especially in terms of managing wildlife and forest resources

A working model for integrating management of PAs and wider production landscapes is piloted and adopted in six districts in North Eastern Uganda Kitgum Kaabong Agago Otuke Abim and Kotido and secures wildlife corridors and dispersal areas covering approximately 227389 ha resulting in reduced deforestation of shea by 25

Consultations with six pilot districts and members of parliament initiated The importance of landscape approach to management of Kidepo National Park and migratory route including Shea belt dispersal area in the process of being mapped out

description.narrative: Ecological stability of entire landscape is increased biodiversity is less threatened and habitats are secured

comment.narrative: Landscape level approaches will not be taken up to the extent that the opportunity allows risks from Climate change will impact the buffer zones but also PAs themselves with net loss to biodiversity and to incomes

Effective Terrestrial protected area coverage increased from a baseline of Increased coverage of PA by 95600 ha over a baseline of 240075 ha and designation of buffer zones to conserve dry season refugia for wildlife 227389 Hectares
Still early to report on the development objective

comment.narrative: The existing baseline is centred on KVNP as the core area where wildlife are able to peacefully habitat refugia are limited and insecure corridors like Karenga are under threat

description.narrative: Poaching levels will have decreased

comment.narrative: Enforcement in the Kidepo Critical Landscape is currently too weak to deal with armed poachers from politically unstable South Sudan and poaching is a growing problem

description.narrative: Six district governments Kitgum Kaabong Agago Otuke Abim and Kotido are collaborating on shared management issues

comment.narrative: No mechanism is presently in place for joint management planning for natural resource use by local governments in the critical landscape

District governments in six districts cooperate effectively to regulate and plan natural resource use over 227389 Ha of the critical landscape resulting in a landscape level coordination mechanism that enshrines biodiversity conservation by mandate

Interdistrict coordination mechanism on enforcement and awareness in place and operational involving district political and technical staff It is coordinated by the Resident District Commissioner of Otuke district for the 4 shea butter tree oilt districts of Kitgum Agago Otuke and Abim

comment.narrative: Management activities are carried out on NP CFR district and community levels but with a lack of a landscape level coordination mechanism

Mechanisms landscape level coordinated management plans and institutional governance systems for enhancing sustainable management of Kidepo critical landscape promoted with landscape management plan in place and enforced
No progress but planned for next year

description.narrative: District governments in six districts of Kitgum Kaabong Agago Otuke Abim and Kotido have proven capacity for managing natural resources sustainably

comment.narrative: District Governments lack the competence and staff skills to monitor and enforce laws As a result there is a lack of understanding of the situation visàvis sustainable hunting and Shea utilization leading to habitat degradation

Local Governments have the competence and staff skills to monitor and enforce laws on sustainable hunting and sustainable use of Shea tree in target districts measured by a 40 increase in scores in capacity development scorecard
In order to improve on the competence and staff skills of local governments enforcement officers from one district Otuke were trained during a two days workshop on enforcement

description.narrative: Existence of interdistrict coordination body in place and functioning with an M E Plan

comment.narrative: There is no District coordination mechanism in place leading to a lack of coordination over the management of crucial savannah woodland habitats Shea trees and wildlife

A District coordination mechanism in place in the project target area six districts to ensure that biodiversity management in National Parks Central forest reserves and wildlife migration corridors and dispersal areas is factored into integrated decisionmaking governing land use management

As a first step towards formation of a district coordination mechanism for biodiversity management in National Parks CFRs and wildlife corridors a district task force on enforcement comprising of Resident District Commissioners RDCs and District Environment Officers of Kitgum Agago Otuke Abim Kaabong and Kotido was formed Similarly engagement done with cultural leaders in the six project districts of Abim Kaabong Kotido Otuke Agago and Kitgum was another starting point for formation of an interdistrict coordination mechanism

description.narrative: Management plan including zonation plan and regulations in place

comment.narrative: Management plans and regulations critical for wildlife dispersal are presently nonexistent in the wider landscape

Management plans and regulations on BDfriendly management in blocks identified as critical for wildlife dispersal developed and applied by local governmentsresulting in security of buffer zones and wildlife corridors

In order to fasten the management planning process for critical dispersal areas and formulation of regulations for BDfriendly management in identified blocks incentives in form of community livelihood improvement projects were initiated whereby four community project proposals were approved for funding

description.narrative: National export strategy for shea products in place 25 increase in sales an operational market information centre for shea products Certified products in marketplace

comment.narrative: The Shea nut butter market is currently not yielding sufficient returns to producers to justify the conservation of Shea average yields are 1225 kghouseholdyear and average prices for oil 2500 UGX per litre

Measures to improve market access for Shea products in place and employment and income generation among rural women in the pilot area increased through access to markets leading to a 30 rise in the value of shea products and a 25 increase in sales from start of project
No progress this year but planned for next year

description.narrative: Ordinances and bylaws and being enforced by EoP

comment.narrative: District ordinances and community bylaws are nonexistent for Shea tree harvesting and wildlife hunting

District ordinances and community bylaws on the harvest of Shea trees and wildlife hunting reinstated or developed resulting in 25 reduction in shea tree deforestation and a 50 drop in the use of shea for charcoal

To kick start the development and or reinstatement of district ordinances and community bye laws on harvest of shea butter tree products and wildlife hunting the District Council and technical staff of Abim including cultural leaders from the six project districts were sensitized

description.narrative: Sustainable use options a Shea and b wildlife species that are regulated for sport hunting are implemented and the data is available for operational use

comment.narrative: No data available for sustainable use options for Shea tree harvesting and wildlife hunting as a result there is unsustainable use of key species
Operational updated data in place and Sustainable use options for Shea tree resources and wildlife established and implemented

To enable determination of sustainable use options for shea tree resources and wildlife Inventory of shea butter trees and resources as well as animal counts in Karenga Community Wildlife Area were conducted to provide data on status of both shea butter trees and resources including key animal species

description.narrative: Strengthening management effectiveness of the Kidepo Critical Landscape PA cluster
Existence of functional and operational management structure in Kidepo PA and CFRs systems

comment.narrative: The Kidepo Cluster PAs CFRs and Karenga lack operational capacity human resources and equipment to manage secure PA operations such as fires control poaching and monitoring

Establish a security and enforcement system with a platform for information sharing and intelligence gathering among parks and other institutions with databases that will be continuously updated Includes provision of surveillance equipment ranger uniforms fire management tools

As a first step towards strengthening management effectiveness in the Kidepo Critical Landscape PA cluster sensitization meetings with the local leadership including Area Members of Parliament in the project area were conducted and their buyin on biodiversity conservation secured

description.narrative: No of UWA and NFA rangers district government staff NFA and UWA administrative staff trained

comment.narrative: UWA and NFA rangers District government staff UWA and NFA admin staff are inadequately trained in conflict resolution policing tourism customer care fire management and law enforcement
120 UWA and NFA rangers 12 district government staff 30 NFA staff and UWA administration staff including at least 30 women

To improve on UWAs capacity in terms of numbers to monitor wildlife and habitats plus handling humanwildlife conflict community wildlife scouts were trained on simple animal and habitat data collection methods

description.narrative: Number of security and enforcement systems platforms for information sharing and intelligence gathering in the PA cluster

comment.narrative: There is no security and enforcement system as well as a platform for information sharing and intelligence gathering in the PA cluster
At least one security and enforcement system one platform for information sharing and one intelligence gathering mechanism established
To boost the security enforcement mechanisms of the PA cluster equipment GPS radio motor rollers binoculars water bottles knives first aid kits for Ranger use during enforcement patrols procured

description.narrative: Number of sustainable financing plans for the PA cluster

comment.narrative: There are no sustainable financing plans for the PA cluster
At least two sustainable financing plans developed
No progress but planned for next year

title.narrative: Local Development and Social Cohesion in Northern Uganda

Local Development and Social Cohesion in Northern Uganda. It’s aimed at strengthening post-conflict recovery process, strengthening the foundation for development; and to narrow the gap between Northern Uganda region and rest of the country.
third-order administrative division
policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative:
1.Crime statistics disaggregated by category - 69% of counties indicate that land conflicts are a problem - 58% of cases reported are those related to violence against women and children - The average annual increase in crime rate is 20% 2.Number of targeted people that have undergone training and enter the job market disaggregated by gender and type of training; - 58% of Uganda's unemployed are youth - Approximately 500,000 people enter the job market annually while jobs created do not exceed 150,000 per year.
3. No infrastructure provided and training carried out for data collection and management
4.No data for development planning at local government level - Ineffectual capacity of Local Governments to manage participatory planning - Ineffective involvement of CBOs and NGOs with the local government

- 11% reduction in crime statistics - Skills of 300 Out-of-School rural youth (195M, 105F) were enhanced in entrepreneurship. - Vocational training practical facilities for youth and other vulnerable groups in place. There are 2 vocational schools in Northern Uganda, a) Nakapiripirit and b) Anaka Technical Schools supported; -Data for development planning at local government level in place

i). Two vocational schools training facilities in Northern Uganda refurbished for youth to access practical skills ii). 32 Groups of youth and women (960) from Refugee hosting communities in Northern Uganda skilled in business and entrepreneurship iii). One film for Northern Uganda transformational Story produced. iv).4 Rapid response police posts at border with South Sudan and Kenya equipped and functional v). Community policing initiatives implemented along 4 border points in Northern Uganda

i). Two vocational technical training schools in Northern Uganda, one in Karamoja Sub Region - Moroto Technical and the other in Acholi Sub Region - Anaka Technical Institute were refurbished for youth to access practical skills ii). Skills of 38 Groups of youth and women from Local and refugee hosting communities in Northern Uganda enhanced in business and entrepreneurship. The groups are now engaged in income generating activities. iii). A documentary film on the transformation story of the people of Northern Uganda produced and its premier screening done to Development partners, political leaders and local leadership from Northern Uganda.

1.National charcoal survey finalized validated, approved and database established The national Charcoal survey was finalized and launched for use in updating the database for parameters in the value chain related to production, marketing and transportation. 2. Framework for institutional coordination and resource mobilization in place. The action plans were developed, approved by District councils and integrated in the DDPs. Draft ordinances have been developed and the process to procure a facilitator for the development of charcoal trading guidelines. The process of reviewing charcoal certification schemes is on-going by UNBS. 3. Awareness and educational program on local ordinances and standards for sustainable charcoal was completed.The communication strategy has been finalized and adopted by the MEMD, and is informing the awareness program now and in the future. 4. 4 districts manage and establish dedicated renewable biomass feed stocks and supply improved kilns with renewable biomass 300of 700 planned sample plots have been established in 2 districts of the project area. The activity is still on-going in the other 2 districts 5.Conservation agriculture practices piloted across 240hectares. Up to 16groups of farmers, each with 20members (505 women), have been introduced to CA , covering at least 15 hectare per group. The farmers have realized doubled yields of maize and beans; with conservation compared to conventional agriculture practices.

comment.narrative: 1. 2,500 hectares of land under Climate Smart Agriculture practices in target districts 2 No school in the 5 districts integrate CSA 3 1 private sector input actor (Uganda National Agro Inputs Dealers Association) participate in supply of quality inputs on market 4 No input credit system established per district 5 1 artisan (TONNET Enterprise Limited) trained in production of CSA tools 6 No Producer Associations identified, trained and supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Associations. 7 No lessons on CSA documented and disseminated. Limited knowledge management, no clear mechanism for generating and sharing lessons. 8 No trials for CSA technologies carried out 9 No publication of findings and recommendations

1. At least 10,000 hectares put under CSA practices by 3,500 farmers in the five targeted districts of Bugiri, Busia, Budaka, Namutumba and Buyende. 2. At least 30 schools in the 5 districts integrate CSA in their gardens. 3. 5 private sector actors supply quality inputs for CSA up scaling/to Extend CSA Technologies. 4. At least one input credit system established per district 5. At least 12 artisans trained in production of CSA tools. 6. At least 15 producer associations/private sector actors supported to participate in the supply of quality inputs on market. 7. Lessons on CSA documented and available for dissemination. . 8. Trials on at least four (4) CSA technologies carried out. 9. At least 2 publications of findings and recommendations.

1. 800 ha was put under CSA practices in the 5 districts 2. 30 schools integrated CSA in their school gardens, particularly conservation agriculture including use of permanent planting basins and mulching for minimum tillage, soil and water conservation structures, early planting and use of improved quality seeds. This activity included 250 girls, 350 boys in the 5 districts. 3. 15 private sector actors participated in the farmer open days and 4 private sector players supplied quality inputs for CSA up scaling/to Extend CSA Technologies.including oxen driven rippers, herbicides and pesticides and fertilizers. 4. No input credit system established per district but farmer associations were developed to build capacity for growth of home grown credit systems.. 5. Ten(10) local artisans were trained in fabrication of tools including single rippers, and were equipped with tool boxes and start up kits. 6. At least 20 producer associations/private sector actors participated in the 5 district level platforms set up for interaction between service providers/input suppliers. 7. Lessons on CSA documented and available for dissemination. 8. Trials on at least four (4) CSA technologies were carried out. 9. recommendations for national up-scaling of CSA were made for nation wide dissemination

1. CSA practices expanded to 75 hectares of land put under CSA practices by individual farmers [31 farmers (14 women)] and 16 groups of farmers(.each with 20-25 members; 50% women) 2. Ten (10) local artisans trained and provided with startup toolkits to enable them start fabricating equipment and tools like yokes and rippers; 3 farmer cooperatives formed and registered at district level, t 3.One CSA technology for which trials are carried out. i.e Methodology for monitoring CSA impacts finalized and disseminated for use by extension workers.

1. CSA practices were expanded to 75 hectares of land put under CSA practices by individual farmers [31 farmers (14 women)] and 16 groups of farmers(.each with 20-25 members; 50% women) 2. Ten (10) local artisans were trained and provided with startup toolkits. This enabled them start fabricating equipment and tools like yokes and rippers; 3 farmer cooperatives were formed and registered at district level, they have started operations especially collective marketing; and Private sector- farmer interaction forum were facilitated for 6 private sector actors and 50 farmers (21 women) from the 5 districts, and belonging to different farmer cooperatives attended. MoUs were developed with input suppliers and success stories were documented. 3. One CSA technology is in place and trials are carried out. i.e Methodology for monitoring CSA impacts was finalized and disseminated for use by extension workers.

Output 1 1. 50% of the bills completed 2. 39% of enacted laws that are implemented 3. 95.8% of completed to registered cases 4. 2 bills that are human rights compliant enacted into laws 5. Electoral Commission Partially (2) meet the minimum core function performance benchmarks. 6. Evidence that the process of operationalizing a functional Leadership forum(Parliament, Elders forum) has started Output 2 1. 4 democracy institutions with functional e-governance systems 2. 60 districts in Northern and Eastern Uganda with a complete chain of frontline Output 3 1. There is progress of establishing an inclusive and functional Civil Society’s engagement platform in place. 2. 35 Members of Parliament and 10 CSOs equipped with knowledge and advocacy skills on accountability for gender laws and policies Output 4 1. 769 number of LCI, II and III court officials trained 2. 26% of cases are disposed through alternative dispute resolutions 3. 3 country diagnostic studies are conducted to inform policy options on national response to sustainability and scalable models.

1. Five (5) analytical/diagnostic studies were conducted and they informed policy options on national response to sustainability and scalable models. 2. Parliament held a radio talk show and a panel discussion on the theme: “Democratic Governance and SDGs in Uganda: Challenges and Prospects”. This sensitized Members of parliament about Parliament’s role in the implementation of the 2030 Global Agenda. Consequently, a motion to debate the role of Parliament in implementation of the SDGs was moved in Parliamentary session of the day. In addition, Newspaper supplements were also run in the New vision and Daily Monitor. 3. Trained 23 Journalists (12 Female and 10 Male) under Training of Trainers (TOT) in evidence based, development reporting and conflict sensitive journalism focused on human rights and rule of law. i. Parliament held an intensive Post –Elections Induction Seminar for Members of the 10th Parliament. The Induction equipped the newly-elected members with necessary knowledge and information on; ii. The doctrine of separation of powers, checks & balances iii. The role of Parliament in national governance iv. The legislative process v. Parliamentary practices &procedures, privileges, immunities and etiquette. vi. The National Development Plan, vii. Budgeting process and the Sustainable Development Goals.
4. Trained Programme team 28 people (10 Female & 18 Male) in the areas of Human Rights Based Approach, Equal Opportunities and Gender Equality for programme development, planning and implementation. 5. The Electoral Commission’s (EC) capacity was enhanced. Technical experts in voter and civic education, conflict resolution, and public relations and media were employed by UNDP and deployed to the EC. This boosted public trust in the EC and subsequently accounted for a larger voter turnout during the 2016 national election. To-date the EC partially meet the minimum core function performance bench marks. 6. One (01) democracy institution has a functional e-
